source.36ee37d6: # **Conclusion** "Diaphragmatic pacing should not be a routine treatment for patients with ALS in respiratory failure. A subgroup of patients might experience a benefit; however, this possibility should not be assumed. Their findings suggest that insertion of the NeuRx RA/4 Diaphragm Pacing System at the point an individual with ALS develops respiratory insufficiency is harmful." "Whether there is a point earlier in the disease trajectory when implantation and pacing might be of benefit is unknown and is currently being investigated. A poor prognosis and the absence of curative treatment understandably encourage a nothing to lose approach in patients and some clinicians alike, with an attendant lowering of the standards of evidence needed to adopt a new intervention.Their findings show the potential for harm that can arise from adopting this approach." Authors: DiPALS Writing Committee. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1474442215001520
source.713ffd05: # **Diaphragm Pacing May Be Harmful in ALS** Author: by Kristina Fiore "Diaphragmatic pacing may be more harmful than helpful in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), researchers reported." "In a randomized controlled trial that was stopped early, patients treated with the NeuRx 4/4 Diaphragm Pacing System had more than a two-fold increased risk of death during the study than those who only had noninvasive ventilation." "Researchers found that survival was shorter when diaphragmatic pacing was added to the mix. A total of 78% of patients in the pacing group died, compared with 51% of those who had noninvasive ventilation alone." "Survival was significantly worse in those who had the diaphragm added to their treatment (11 months versus 22.5 months)." https://www.medpagetoday.org/neurology/generalneurology/52940
source.43587a89: # **Indications and Contraindications ** "Diaphragm pacing is performed to provide ventilatory support in 2 main clinical scenarios: "Central alveolar ventilation, or what is better known as sleep apnea. "High spinal cord paralysis in which the drive for respiration is still present but the injury to the spinal cord prevents stimulation from the phrenic nerves". **DPS Contraindications** "Diaphragm pacing is contraindicated for patients in whom the phrenic nerve is not functional. Such patients include those with severe traumatic injury to the nerve, those with nerve tumors, and most of those with neuropathies. In addition, diaphragm pacing is contraindicated for patients with conditions in which the diaphragm itself is not functional." https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1970348-overview#a4
source.be706d1b: # **Diaphragm Pacing System (DPS) Background** Author: Shabir Bhimji "The history of pacing the diaphragm is not new. The earliest record of phrenic stimulation for the treatment of asphyxia was reported in 1783. In the mid-1850s, French neurologists also proposed such an idea, but it was Hugo Wilhelm von Ziemssen who performed the first diaphragmatic pacing on a young female patient who had asphyxiated on charcoal vapor." "The true beginnings of diaphragmatic pacing started in the 1860s and 70s. The father of modern diaphragm pacing is Dr William W L Glenn from Yale University, who showed that the technique was not only practical but could be used clinically for the treatment for several medical disorders. With advances in technology, more refined and flexible electrodes were developed, and the thoracoscopic method of implantation became practical." https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1970348-overview#a4
source.e5242d2f:
Diaphragm pacing system implanted in a patient with ALS

Citation: Kotan D, Kaymak K, Gündogdu AA. Diaphragm pacing system implanted in a patient with ALS. J Back Musculoskelet Rehabil. 2016 Aug 10;29(3):611-2. doi: 10.3233/BMR-150637. PMID: 26444327. "The diaphragm pacing system (DPS) is a life quality improving operation in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) patients who need mechanical ventilation or have chronic respiratory insufficiency. This procedure is gaining in popularity, and the number of centers implanting diaphragm pacing systems (DPS) is increasing. DPS delays the need for a ventilation machine in the early stages of Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) disease. In this case study, we present a young female ALS patient. A DPS was implanted after respiratory insufficiency began. In the one-year follow-up period following her operation, her need for ventilatory support disappeared." https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26444327/
source.9ed1fa92:
Safety and efficacy of diaphragm pacing in patients with respiratory insufficiency due to amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (DiPALS): a multicentre, open-label, randomised controlled trial

Authors: DiPALS Writing Committee on behalf of the DiPALS Study Group Collaborators "Survival was shorter in the non-invasive ventilation plus pacing group than in the non-invasive ventilation alone group (median 11·0 months vs 22·5 months; adjusted hazard ratio 2·27, 95% CI 1·22–4·25; p=0·009). 28 (76%) patients died in the pacing group and 19 (51%) patients died in the non-invasive ventilation alone group. The authors recorded 162 adverse events (5·9 events per person-year) in the pacing group, of which 46 events were serious, compared with 81 events (2·5 events per person-year) in the non-invasive ventilation alone group, of which 31 events were serious." "Addition of diaphragm pacing to standard care with non-invasive ventilation was associated with decreased survival in patients with ALS. The results suggest that diaphragmatic pacing should not be used as a routine treatment for patients with ALS in respiratory failure." "Case series of the spinal cord injury and ALS populations have emphasised the apparent simplicity and operative safety of the NeuRx RA/4 Diaphragm Pacing System. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1474442215001520
